<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 297, 393, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 338, 415, 354]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 368, 374]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 715, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 500, 255, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 526, 769, 558]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 567, 760, 598]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 124, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 103, 635, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{ms}^{- 2}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 102, 620, 121]]<|/det|>
\[c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 107, 561, 144]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 527, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = p\Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 195, 537, 225]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 263, 561, 295]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 305, 537, 322]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 339, 616, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_0\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_0^2 - x^2)}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 384, 537, 420]]<|/det|>
\[f_0 = \frac{f_s\nu}{\nu\pm\nu_s}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 430, 537, 465]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 472, 628, 490]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_1 + 1 / C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 504, 596, 523]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_1 + C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 533, 527, 560]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 574, 531, 592]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 607, 596, 625]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 640, 628, 658]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 672, 517, 705]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 718, 561, 736]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 752, 581, 770]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 780, 536, 814]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 325, 720, 344]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 368, 920, 387]]<|/det|>
The spring of unstretched length \(0.40 \text{m}\) has one end attached to a fixed point, as shown in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 672, 920, 721]]<|/det|>
A block of weight \(2.5 \text{N}\) is then attached to the spring. The block is then released and begins to move downwards. At one instant, as the block is continuing to move downwards, the spring has a length of \(0.72 \text{m}\), as shown in Fig. 3.3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A loudspeaker oscillates with frequency \(f\) to produce sound waves of wavelength \(\lambda\). The loudspeaker makes \(N\) oscillations in time \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 181, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 787, 136]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 149, 223, 166]]<|/det|>
<label>1.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 149, 594, 166]]<|/det|>
the distance moved by a wavefront in time \(t\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 195, 917, 212]]<|/det|>

time \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[517, 272, 917, 290]]<|/det|>

Use your answers in (i) to deduce the equation relating the speed \(v\) of the sound wave to \(f\) and \(\lambda\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 429, 920, 448]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 459, 148, 478]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 459, 920, 492]]<|/det|>
The waveform of a sound wave is displayed on the screen of a cathode-ray oscilloscope (c.r.o.), as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 501, 688, 666]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 685, 532, 703]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[482, 901, 920, 919]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 781, 91]]<|/det|>
Two sources \(\mathsf{S}_1\) and \(\mathsf{S}_2\) of sound waves are positioned as shown in Fig. 5.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[304, 98, 690, 280]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 297, 589, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.2 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 329, 920, 378]]<|/det|>
The sources emit coherent sound waves of wavelength \(0.85\mathrm{m}.\) A sound detector is moved parallel to the line \(\mathsf{S}_1\mathsf{S}_2\) from a point X to a point Y. Alternate positions of maximum loudness L and minimum loudness Q are detected, as illustrated in Fig. 5.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 390, 672, 410]]<|/det|>
Distance \(\mathsf{S}_1\mathsf{X}\) is equal to distance \(\mathsf{S}_2\mathsf{X}\). Distance \(\mathsf{S}_2\mathsf{Y}\) is \(7.40\mathrm{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 421, 181, 440]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 421, 542, 440]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 560, 920, 579]]<|/det|>
<form>phase difference = ....................................................... ° [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 591, 180, 610]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 591, 430, 610]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[494, 794, 920, 812]]<|/det|>
<form>distance = ....................................................... m [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 825, 920, 842]]<|/det|>

<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(E\) and internal resistance \(r\) is connected to a variable resistor of resistance \(R\), as shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 109, 688, 266]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 285, 532, 304]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 6.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 317, 848, 336]]<|/det|>
The current in the circuit is \(I\) and the potential difference across the variable resistor is \(V.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 348, 144, 367]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 348, 559, 367]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[851, 408, 920, 427]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 439, 482, 458]]<|/det|>
State an equation relating \(E, I, r\) and \(V.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[851, 469, 920, 488]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 502, 144, 521]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 502, 920, 536]]<|/det|>

Use Fig. 6.2 to:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 920, 354]]<|/det|>
The battery stores \(9.2 \text{kJ}\) of energy. The variable resistor is adjusted so that \(V = 2.1 \text{V}\). Use Fig. 6.2 to:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 475, 920, 509]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
One of the results of the \(\alpha\) -particle scattering experiment is that a very small minority of the \(\alpha\) -particles are scattered through angles greater than \(90^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 771, 136]]<|/det|>
State what may be inferred about the structure of the atom from this result.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 273, 144, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 273, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
A hadron has an overall charge of \(+e,\) where \(e\) is the elementary charge. The hadron contains three quarks. One of the quarks is a strange (s) quark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 320, 180, 338]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 320, 650, 338]]<|/det|>
State the charge, in terms of \(e,\) of the strange (s) quark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[505, 365, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
<form>charge = ....................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 396, 180, 415]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 396, 796, 415]]<|/det|>
The other two quarks in the hadron have the same charge as each other.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 428, 890, 462]]<|/det|>
By considering charge, determine a possible type (flavour) of the other two quarks. Explain your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 615, 920, 632]]<|/det|>
